stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: American Express Card Themed Emails
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 31 October 2014 a U.S. government department observed phishing emails with an American Express card theme. The emails used the sender address pkle@boyle.com, and the subject "Important Information About Your Recent Card". Malicious links in the body of the HTML email directed to http://ayerikam-expresz.com.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- BEGIN EMAIL HEADER ----- EHLO UUYWTRLJ MAIL FROM: <pkle@boyle.com> RCPT TO: <[REDACTED]> DATA Message-ID: <ORX8XLM6.2144286@boyle.com> Date: Fri, 31 Oct 2014 13:13:30 -0500 From: American Express <AmericanExpress@welcome.aexp.com> User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:24.0) Gecko/20100101 Thunderbird/24.2.0 MIME-Version: 1.0 To: <[REDACTED]> Subject: Important Information About Your Recent Card Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="------------000506040105090303030702" ----- END EMAIL HEADER -----
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY ----- Important Information About Your Recent Irregular Card Activity Dear Customer According to our records, we recently noticed irregular activity on your AMERICAN EXPRESS Card. We have changed some of the Card information to protect the security of your account. For your convenience, please update your new Card information or the information you may have on file. To update your information please visit: https://americanexpress.com If you have any questions, please contact us using the number on the back of your Card. Sincerely, American Express Customer Care
Contact Customer Service | View Our Privacy Statement | Add Us to Your Address Book Your Card Member information is included in the upper-right corner to help you recognize this as a customer service e-mail from American Express. Using the spam/junk mail function may not block servicing messages from being sent to your email account. To learn more about e-mail security or report a suspicious e-mail, please visit us at americanexpress.com/phishing. We kindly ask you not to reply to this e-mail but instead contact us securely via customer service.
2014 American Express. All rights reserved. AGNEUSCN0006002 ----- END EMAIL BODY -----
It was reported that the email senders likely copied the text of a legitimate American Express customer service email and spoofed a seemingly legitimate sender email address in an effort to better hide the malicious nature of the email.

The HTML link in the email directs to ayerikam-expresz.com, which resolved to IP address 5.9.184.138 as of 31 October 2014. The domain hosts a number of JavaScript scripts of unknown purpose.
Open source reported query:
GET /americanexpress/ HTTP/1.1 Host: ayerikam-expresz.com User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8 Accept-Language: en-us,en;q=0.5 Accept-Encoding: gzip,deflate Accept-Charset: ISO-8859-1,utf-8;q=0.7,*;q=0.7 Keep-Alive: 115 Connection: keep-alive
Response: 5.9.184.138 HTTP/1.0 200 OK
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 187009 Accept-Ranges: bytes Server: nginx Date: Fri, 31 Oct 2014 17:41:38 GMT Last-Modified: Fri, 31 Oct 2014 17:32:29 GMT Etag: "5453c7ad-2da81" Connection: keep-alive
WHOIS information:
